Amazing night! My wife and I live about 15 min from Vandenberg and we have been goin to every launch for the past 6 years. This launch topped them all! We knew it was going to be packed because of it being the first return to pad landing and the good possibility of twilight effect but had no idea how wild it would actually be. I’ve NEVER seen that many people at a launch. We chose to watch from Ocean Ave over the Hawks nest so we could be closer to then pad. We passed the gate to the Hawks best and there was a line of cars over a mile long waiting for gates to be opened! We got there 3 hours early and Ocean was already packed. We go lucky and squeezed in a perfect spot. There were THOUSANDS of people on Ocean Ave also! People were grilling steaks, playing soccer, throwing frisbees, and a few brought guitars to play music. It was like the Super Bowl tailgate but for a Falcon9 launch and landing!!! Will never forget that!! The sonic booms were just icing on the cake 🚀💥🎯

I have a question, perhaps you know the answer to. Since they have most launches out at Kennedy, and I have watched all the videos of how they transport things to the east coast from their Hawthorne facility. Why hasn't SpaceX built a facility in Florida for production of the rockets? Seems like that is a ton of time and cost wasted on transportation.

I am also assuming they transport them back to Hawthorne once they are recovered on the east coast to be refurbished.

A moment of silence for Hubble.

Another way to look at the angled up rocket substtuting for a circularisation burn is that you're providing both a prograde and outward radial component. The prograde component is accelerating you to orbital speed, the radial component is lifting your orbital path, extending how long it will be before you fall back.
DON'T PANIC

@16:58 Tim gets his facts mixed up a bit about the original "Raptor" Engine.
The original "Raptor" engine was supposed to be Hydrogen 2nd stage. This would have had the ISP advantage over RP-1 Merlin.
However the current development of "Raptor" is now Methane based and only has a small ISP advantage over current Merlin.
(Scott Manley commented on the original Raptor project)
Certainly not enough advantage to justify a complete redevelopment as a 2nd stage for Falcon.

Yesterday morning I made the impulse decision to drive 4 hours each way to get to Vandenberg and watch the launch up close. In most of the videos it just looked like a ball of light but in person I was able to see the actual rocket very clearly and could make out tons of detail through my binoculars! I was pretty close to the pad so everything seemed like it was happening right on top of me and the glowing exhaust was super bright and colorful!
You can see it this time

During the ascent of the rocket, there is part where you can see multiple stars in the background. When moon hoaxers are debunked, they are told that no camera can get the exposure time such, that you can see the lunar surface and stars at the same time. So how is it possible that a camera focused at the extremely bright rocket exhaust can also capture starlight?
